mappings.name: parent
mappings.desc: (Term id) Parent term to create a group

mappings.name: synonyms
mappings.desc: Comma-separated alternative names for this term

terms.name: Accountability for Implementation Delivery
terms.description: The management body is responsible for setting the timeline and milestones of the implementation programme, with one or two members in the management function formally assigned responsibility for execution and regular reporting to the management body in its supervisory function. The management body should receive frequent progress updates and actively assess and address any delays in implementation.

terms.name: Internal Audit Function
terms.description: As the third line of defence, the internal audit function is to periodically provide independent reviews of the data governance framework, RDARR capabilities and processes, the validation function, and the quality of risk data, with reviews complemented where appropriate by supervisory or external independent assessments.

terms.name: Manual Workaround Controls
terms.description: Manual workarounds within scope are to be documented and subject to adequate controls — such as the four-eyes principle, audit trails, and formal sign-offs — until materially impactful data preparation and reporting steps are embedded in an IT-controlled, audit-trailed environment.

terms.name: Oversight of RDARR Remediation and BAU Deliverables
terms.description: Oversight of RDARR remediation and BAU deliverables against agreed timelines is required, along with regular benchmarking against BCBS 239 best practices and a defined institutional interpretation of BCBS 239 that acknowledges any technical or legal limitations to full data aggregation.

terms.name: Data Taxonomy Management
terms.description: Data taxonomy management is to ensure uniform data definitions with clear ownership, defined validation rules, and complete, up-to-date data lineage at data-attribute level for in-scope risk indicators and critical data elements.

terms.name: Central Data Governance Function
terms.description: A central data governance function is to be established, responsible for issuing data quality policies and processes, overseeing implementation of the data governance framework, monitoring and assessing data quality, and participating in material change initiatives affecting RDARR — including mergers and acquisitions, outsourcing, new products, and significant IT changes.

terms.name: Risk Model Scope
terms.description: Key internal risk management models fall within the scope, including Pillar 1 regulatory capital models (e.g. IRB approaches for credit risk), Pillar 2 risk and capital models, and other material risk models, covering both critical input data and key model outputs used for risk management.

terms.name: Effective implementation programmes
terms.description: Institutions that have not yet met BCBS 239 best practices are expected to implement structured remediation programmes to address identified gaps and weaknesses, underpinned by strong governance, adequate resources, and regular progress reporting.

terms.name: Data Quality Indicators and Reporting
terms.description: Data quality indicators are to be defined and measured across accuracy, integrity, completeness, and timeliness, with tolerance levels, documented breach correction processes, lifecycle-wide monitoring and recording, and periodic reporting to the management body — including impact analysis on risk measurement effectiveness and the institution's risk profile. (Exemplified in https://www.bankingsupervision.europa.eu/ecb/pub/pdf/ssm.thematicreviewcercompendiumgoodpractices112022~b474fb8ed0.en.pdf, sec. 4.5.1)

terms.name: RDARR as Strategic Priority
terms.description: RDARR is to be treated as a strategic priority, backed by sufficient resources and a robust data governance framework that defines clear data quality standards and KPIs for monitoring accuracy, integrity, completeness, and timeliness, in both normal and stress conditions.

terms.name: Integrated Group-Wide Data Architecture
terms.description: An integrated, group-wide data architecture is to be implemented and documented, including data dictionaries and metadata repositories, covering all material entities, risks, reports, key risk indicators, critical data elements, and in-scope models, with consistency ensured across risk types and legal entities.

terms.name: BCBS 239 - Structured Remediation
terms.description: Structured remediation programmes are to be implemented in response to findings from internal and external reviews, including on-site inspections and off-site assessments by ECB Banking Supervision. Effective implementation requires strong project governance, clear controls over execution risks, and sufficient financial, technical, and human resources. Plans should set out concrete remedial actions, milestones, responsibilities, and interim measures where full remediation will take time. Institutions should also assess the impact of implementation on internal models, financial reporting integration, and broader business and ICT strategies. Programmes should be ambitious but realistic, with regular progress reporting that highlights delays, obstacles, and execution risks.

terms.name: Designated RDARR Responsibility
terms.description: One or two members of the management body — or, where applicable, senior managers with direct access to it — are to be designated as responsible for implementing the data governance framework, without reducing or transferring the overall accountability of the full management body.

terms.name: Report Production Time and Decision-Making Effectiveness
terms.description: The time required to produce risk reports is as important as reporting frequency for effective risk management. Delays in report preparation prolong uncertainty about the institution's risk position and increase the risk of slow or inadequate management responses.

terms.name: Sufficient scope of application
terms.description: An integrated, group-wide data governance framework is to be established, covering all material entities, risks, business lines, and reporting processes across the full data lifecycle, with a clearly defined and proportionate scope aligned to the institution's risk profile.

terms.name: End-to-End Data Quality Controls
terms.description: Data quality controls are to be implemented end-to-end from source systems to the reporting layer for key risk indicators and critical data elements, covering accuracy, integrity, completeness, and timeliness, with automation where appropriate and periodic reconciliation with internal and external sources, including model development data.

terms.name: Integrated data architecture
terms.description: The technical backbone of effective RDARR: a documented, group-wide data architecture that ensures the consistency, transparency, and traceability of all data used for risk, supervisory, and financial reporting.

terms.name: Collective Suitability Assessment
terms.description: Data management, IT, and financial and non-financial risk knowledge, skills, and experience are to be factored into the assessment and regular review of the collective suitability of management body members.

terms.name: Data Lineage
terms.description: Data lineage describes how data moves and changes from its initial capture in source systems through all transformations, aggregations, and transfers until it is used in reports or risk indicators. It enables institutions to verify data quality controls, ensure transformation consistency, support ad hoc reporting, trace data quality issues to their source, and provide traceability for internal and external validation.

terms.name: Data Attribute
terms.description: A data attribute describes a data element and provides its metadata, such as its business meaning, data type, format, or allowed values. In practice, data attributes are stored as columns or metadata fields and are used in data mappings and transformations to calculate key risk indicators.

terms.name: Risk Appetite and Key Risk Indicators Scope
terms.description: Risk appetite indicators and other key risk indicators used in internal risk, financial, and supervisory reporting and models are to be included in the scope, with the institution defining the indicator set based on its risk profile and explicitly identifying the underlying critical data elements.

terms.name: Group-Level RDARR Consistency
terms.description: RDARR policies and processes are to be implemented consistently at group level, while the management bodies of subsidiaries remain responsible for applying and executing these group-wide requirements within their respective entities.

terms.name: Meaningful Internal Risk Reporting
terms.description: The management body should regularly ensure internal risk reports are meaningful, balanced, and support sound decision‑making.

terms.name: Data Quality KPI Monitoring and Controls
terms.description: Data quality KPIs and action plans are to be regularly monitored, with robust data quality processes and controls maintained throughout.

terms.name: Regular RDARR Training for Management Body
terms.description: Regular, role-appropriate training is required to ensure members maintain sufficient and up-to-date knowledge of the institution's business, data management, IT, and financial and non-financial risks, and their impact on operations.

terms.name: RDARR Roles and Responsibilities Across the Institution
terms.description: RDARR roles and responsibilities are to be clearly defined and assigned across the business, including relevant committees, in line with the specific role definitions set out in Section 3.3.

terms.name: Group-wide data quality management and standards
terms.description: Group-wide policies and processes are to be established within the risk management or data governance framework to ensure effective data quality controls, remediation of material issues, transparency of limitations, and appropriate management of data quality risks.

terms.name:
Full Accountability for Data Quality and
 Governance
terms.description: Full accountability for risk data quality and governance sits with the management body, as an integral part of the overall risk management framework.

terms.name: Data Ownership
terms.description: Data owners are to be designated for key risk indicators and underlying critical data elements across the full data aggregation lifecycle, with responsibilities covering the definition of data quality controls, ensuring accuracy, integrity, completeness and timeliness, monitoring and reporting data quality, remediating issues, and managing metadata such as data lineage and data dictionaries.

terms.name: Independent Validation Function
terms.description: An independent second-line validation function is to regularly assess the effectiveness of RDARR processes across all material entities and risk types, covering all RDARR components, while ensuring adequate segregation of duties, sufficient expertise and resources, and effective oversight of outsourced activities and material change initiatives.

terms.name: End-User Computing Management
terms.description: End-user computing applications and end-user developed tools are to be fully integrated into data quality management policies and processes, supported by an up-to-date overview of all such applications.

terms.name: Responsibilities of the management body
terms.description: The management body is ultimately responsible for RDARR, ensuring effective risk identification, aggregation, reporting, and controls in line with CRD and EBA guidelines, supported by strong risk culture and sufficient management-level expertise.

terms.name: Data Quality Risk in ICAAP and ILAAP
terms.description: Data quality risks are to be appropriately reflected in ICAAP and ILAAP, given that data quality issues may lead to risk underestimation and should be addressed through additional conservatism in risk quantification.

terms.name: Calibrating Reporting Speed to Risk Appetite
terms.description: Both reporting frequency and report production time are to be calibrated to ensure timely responses to changes in the institution's risk profile and continued compliance with internal risk appetite indicators. In normal conditions, a monthly or quarterly risk report taking more than 20 working days to produce is generally considered too slow to support timely management action, with appropriate production times depending on the materiality and volatility of the key risk indicators being reported.

terms.name: Data Quality Issue Management
terms.description: An up-to-date and complete overview of data quality issues and limitations is to be maintained, covering severity assessments, root cause analyses, quantitative impact analyses on affected risk and business areas, clearly defined remediation and escalation processes proportionate to issue materiality, defined remediation deadlines, and recorded remediation dates supported by appropriate evidence.

terms.name: Aligning Reporting Frequency with Risk Dynamics
terms.description: Internal risk reporting should reflect how quickly risk exposures can change: the more dynamic the risk, the more frequent the reporting. Regulatory guidance supports this approach — the ECB's Guide to the ICAAP, for example, expects reporting to senior management at least quarterly, with higher frequencies where an institution's size, complexity, business model, or risk profile warrants faster intervention. Reporting needs also vary by risk type, as economic risk measures tend to be more volatile than normative measures and therefore require more frequent monitoring.

terms.name: Minimum Reporting Scope
terms.description: At a minimum, the framework's scope is to cover internal risk reports used for decision-making and risk steering, externally published financial reports and annual financial statements, and supervisory reporting, including FINREP/COREP, stress test submissions, and Pillar 3 disclosures.

terms.name: Data Element
terms.description: A data element is the actual piece of information stored or reported — such as a value used in calculations or reporting (e.g. Loan Outstanding Amount = 1,250,000 EUR) — and directly determines the resulting values of key risk indicators such as exposure amounts or risk metrics.

terms.name: Effective data governance framework
terms.description: A clear allocation of data quality roles, responsibilities, and ownership is to be established across all organisational levels and across business, internal control, and IT functions, formalised in approved and regularly reviewed group-wide policies.

terms.name: Management Body Competence in Data and Risk
terms.description: Members of the management body and heads of internal control functions are expected to hold sufficient understanding, skills, and experience in data management, IT, and financial and non-financial risks — including climate-related risks — to assess financial implications and support effective decision-making.

terms.name: Stress-Ready Risk Data and Reporting Capabilities
terms.description: Beyond routine reporting, robust RDARR capabilities are to be maintained for stress and crisis situations, supporting the management of unexpected shocks and enabling rapid adaptation to new or revised reporting and disclosure requirements. During periods of emerging stress, institutions must be able to respond promptly to ad hoc data requests at both entity and group level — with sufficient granularity, such as customer-level data to manage credit risk concentrations — without being hindered by fragmented IT systems or heavy reliance on manual processes.

relations.sourceTerm: Management Body Competence in Data and Risk

Full Accountability for Data Quality and
 Governance
Calibrating Reporting Speed to Risk Appetite
relations.targetTerm: Risk Appetite and Key Risk Indicators Scope
relations.name: operationalises
enables
relations.description: Data lineage transparency is a precondition for the second-line validation function to effectively assess RDARR processes: without a clear view of how data moves from source to report, the validation function cannot reliably determine whether data quality controls are correctly placed, whether transformations are consistent with agreed definitions, or where data quality issues originate.

relations.sourceTerm: Stress-Ready Risk Data and Reporting Capabilities
relations.name: depends on

relations.targetTerm: Risk Appetite and Key Risk Indicators Scope
relations.name: underlies
relations.description: The critical data elements that institutions are required to explicitly identify under P2.3 as part of their risk appetite and key risk indicator scope are, in practice, the data elements defined here as C1 — the actual values (e.g. exposure amounts, loan balances) that directly determine the resulting indicator values used in risk, financial, and supervisory reporting.

relations.targetTerm: Group-wide data quality management and standards

relations.sourceTerm: Regular RDARR Training for Management Body
Stress-Ready Risk Data and Reporting Capabilities
Group-wide data quality management and standards

relations.name: supports
relations.description: Data owners managing metadata under P3.1 are in practice managing data attributes — the business definitions, data types, formats, and allowed values stored in data dictionaries and metadata repositories. Clear and complete data attributes are what make meaningful metadata management possible.

relations.targetTerm: Group-wide data quality management and standards

relations.name: enables
relations.description: End-to-end data lineage supports the internal audit function's independent reviews by providing the traceability needed to verify that data quality controls are operating as intended throughout the data flow, and to trace any data quality issues back to their source — without which audit findings would rely on incomplete evidence.
